text:
A great interview with a scientist who wrote a phylogentics package in Julia
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Byhc0tksgSk&feature=emb_logo>

elements.text: A great interview with a scientist who wrote a phylogentics package in Julia

text:
In this conversation with Claudia Solis-Lemus (<https://solislemuslab.github.io/>) we talk about SNaQ, her tool for reconstructing phylogenetic networks in the presence of incomplete lineage sorting and hybridization.

The SNaQ paper, which describes many of the methods and parameters we discuss:
Claudia Solís-Lemus and Cécile Ané (2016). Inferring Phylogenetic Networks with Maximum Pseudolikelihood under Incomplete Lineage Sorting. PLoS Genet 12(3):e1005896. doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1005896

text:
I'm curious why you rolled your own graph network library and didn't build on switch/extend something like LightGraph.
Is that a consequence from the early C-style work?

elements.text:
I'm curious why you rolled your own graph network library and didn't build on switch/extend something like LightGraph.
Is that a consequence from the early C-style work?

text: She says in the video that Julia was 2-3 years old when they started using it, and so there were no libraries to do what they wanted

elements.text: She says in the video that Julia was 2-3 years old when they started using it, and so there were no libraries to do what they wanted

text: <@U01K809EUQ7> which is why i also said switch/extend
That's very cool. I'll definitely check that out next time I need to work with phylogenetics! :)

elements.text: That's very cool. I'll definitely check that out next time I need to work with phylogenetics! :)
